meanings.def: a set of printed pages that are fastened inside a cover so that you can turn them and read them
examples: His desk was covered with piles of books.
hardback/paperback books
a book of short stories
Her name was inscribed in the book.
one of the earliest printed books

meanings.def: a written work published in printed or electronic form
examples: to read/write/publish a book
reference/children's/library books
book by somebody a new book by J. K. Rowling
book about something a book about wildlife
book on something He has written a book on local architecture.
Have you read her latest book?
Do you want to renew any of your library books?
His latest book will appear in December.
How many books can I borrow?
How many books have you got out?
How many copies of the book did you order?
I couldn't put the book down.
She looked up from her book and smiled at him.
She's busy writing a book on astrology.
The book is dedicated to his mother.

There's nothing like curling up with a mug of tea and a good book.
These issues are discussed in his latest book.
a book for new parents
a book of walks in London
a controversial book about the royal family
a new book from the publishing company, Bookworm
a survey to find the nation's favourite children's book
I'm reading a book by Robert Shea.
The book has received some terrible reviews.
a library/​hardback book

meanings.def: a set of sheets of paper that are fastened together inside a cover and used for writing in
examples: an exercise book
a notebook

meanings.def: a set of things that are fastened together like a book
examples: a book of stamps/tickets/matches
a chequebook

meanings.def: the written records of the financial affairs of a business
examples: to do the books (= to check the accounts)
You need to go over the books again; there’s a mistake somewhere.
She does the books for us.

meanings.def: a section of a large written work
examples: the books of the Bible

meanings.def: a record of bets made on whether something will happen, somebody will win a race, etc.
examples: They’ve opened a book on who’ll win the Championship.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody is pleased/annoyed with you
examples: I'm in her good books at the moment because I cleared up the kitchen.

meanings.def: to punish somebody for doing something wrong and make them explain their behaviour
examples: We will ensure that people who commit fraud are brought to book through the courts.

meanings.def: following rules and instructions in a very strict way
examples: She always does everything by the book.

meanings.def: to stop doing something because you no longer believe you will be successful or will find a solution
examples: The police have closed the book on the case (= they have stopped trying to solve it).

meanings.def: a subject or person that you know nothing about
examples: Nuclear physics is a closed book to most of us.

meanings.def: to change facts or figures dishonestly or illegally
examples: His accountant had been cooking the books for years.
Someone was cooking the books.

meanings.def: used to say that you should not form an opinion about somebody/something from their appearance only
every available method, whether it is honest or not
examples: He'll try every trick in the book to stop you from winning.

meanings.def: to be reading
examples: She always has her nose in a book.

meanings.def: the record of great achievements in history
examples: She has earned her place in the history books.

meanings.def: used when you are giving your opinion
examples: That's cheating in my book.

meanings.def: (to be) on an organization’s list, for example of people who are available for a particular type of work
examples: We have very few nurses on our books at the moment.
Most of the houses on our books are in the north of the city.
We have fifty people on the books.

meanings.def: if you describe somebody or their life as an open book, you mean that you can easily understand them and know everything about them
to understand easily what somebody is thinking or feeling
to be convenient or useful for you/somebody
examples: Well, if you’re honest and hard-working, that suits our book.

meanings.def: to copy somebody’s behaviour and do things in the same way that they do, because they are successful
to punish somebody who has committed an offence as severely as possible
examples: ‘Get this man down to the station and throw the book at him!’ yelled Curtis.

meanings.def: to arrange to have or use something on a particular date in the future; to buy a ticket in advance
examples: Book early to avoid disappointment.
book something She booked a flight to Chicago.
He booked tickets for his trip to New York.
Most customers now book their holidays online.
The performance is booked up (= there are no more tickets available).
I'm sorry—we're fully booked.
(British English) I'd like to book a table for two for 8 o'clock tonight.

meanings.def: to arrange for somebody to have a seat on a plane, etc.
examples: book somebody + adv./prep. I've booked you on the 10 o'clock flight.
book somebody something + adv./prep. I've booked you a room at the Park Hotel.
book somebody something Have you told the office to book you a flight?

meanings.def: to arrange for a singer, etc. to perform on a particular date
examples: We've booked a band for the wedding reception.
